data.title: Kyiv or Kiev? Why the Ukraine capital’s name change matters to the Russia conflict, and how to pronounce it
data.meta_description: The spelling of the capital's name has become something of a touchpoint during the conflict
data.text:
The Ukrainian capital of Kyiv is being bombarded with rocket strikes, as Russia continues its offensive against its Eastern European neighbour.

Photos and videos shared on social media appeared to show huge explosions and columns of smoke filling the sky in Kyiv on Friday morning, as air raid sirens rang across the city.

Foreign Minister Dmytro Kuleba tweeted: “Last time our capital experienced anything like this was in 1941 when it was attacked by Nazi Germany. Ukraine defeated that evil and will defeat this one.”

The spelling of the capital’s name has become something of a touchpoint during the conflict. Britons will be more used to the “Kiev” spelling, but most UK media outlets have recently adopted “Kyiv” instead.

Here is the difference explained.

Is it Kiev or Kyiv?

The Ukrainian capital is known as Київ in Ukrainian and Киев in Russian.

As with many words in languages that use the Cyrillic script, the transliteration of the name into the Roman alphabet is not precise, and it could be spelled variously as Kyiv, Kiev, Kyyiv or Kiyev.

Kiev was the standardised spelling when the city was under the rule of the Soviet Union, and continued to be used after the union dissolved in 1991.

The Ukrainian government legally approved a switch to Kyiv in 1995, but the issue gained added importance for many Ukrainians in 2014, when the pro-Russian leader Viktor Yanukovych was ousted and the country began to seek closer ties with the EU and Nato.

Many Ukrainians see the name Kiev as a relic of the country’s Soviet past, as it is closer to the pronunciation in Russian, whereas Kyiv matches the pronunciation in Ukrainian.

In 2018 the Ukrainian Ministry of Foreign Affairs launched the “KyivNotKiev” campaign, to attempt to persuade other countries to adopt their favoured spelling.

It said at the time: “Ukraine has been an independent sovereign nation for more than 27 years, but the Soviet-era versions of many geographic names stubbornly persist in international practice. The usage of Soviet-era place names – rooted in the Russian language – is unacceptable to the people of Ukraine.”

Campaigns targeted airports, embassies and international media, and the change started to be adopted towards the end of the decade.

Associated Press, a news agency which provides copy to most major English-speaking media outlets, said at the time: “Although the AP prefers traditional English spellings for many cities, including Rome, Moscow and Warsaw (not Roma, Moskva and Warszawa), we regard the Ukrainian spelling of Kyiv as an important adaptation because it is linked to Ukraine’s present status.

“To many Ukrainians, the former spelling Kiev appears outdated because it is associated with a time when Ukraine was part of the Russian and Soviet states, rather than an independent country.”

However, a number of media outlets have only adopted the Kyiv spelling during the current conflict, which is why people are suddenly seeing it far more often. For example, The Daily Mail announced it was making the switch on Friday.

How do you pronounce Kyiv?

The pronunciation of Kyiv is a little different to Kiev.

In English the new spelling is pronounced KEY-eve, rather than KEY-yev.

Vitaly Chernetsky, a Ukrainian-born professor in the Department of Slavic and Eurasian Languages and Literatures at the University of Kansas, told NPR the old pronunciation is still OK when talking about food.

“Just like we can still say Peking duck, it’s OK to say chicken Kiev,” he said.
